titleStmt.title: The Popes brief: or Romes inquiry after the death of their Catholiques here in England, during these times of warre: discovered by two commissions; the one sent from the Pope that now is: the other from the Bishop and Duke of Cambrey, to severall commissioners in England: whereby the death of such Catholiques may be returned to the See of Rome, to be determined of (as may be fit for the glory of God.) Together with a catalogue of the vicars generall, and archdeacons under the Bishop of Calcedon, for the setling of the popish hierarchy in England. With divers letters concerning the same. Also severall letters and papers of the Lord Inchiquines in Ireland, intercepted by the Earl of Warwick, and sent to the House of Commons; wherein is discovered the ungratefull and perfidious dealing of the said Lord with the Parliament of England. Ordered by the Commons in Parliament, that the said Commissions, together with the Hierarchy, and severall letters and papers intercepted, be forthwith printed and published: H: Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Together with A CATALOGUE Of the Vicars Generall, and Archdeacons under the Bi≈øhop of Calcedon, for the ≈øetling of the Popi≈øh Hierarchy in England.
With divers LETTERS concerning the ≈øame.

Al≈øo ≈øeverall LETTERS and PAPERS Of the Lord Inchiquines in Jreland, Intercepted by the Earl of Warwick, and ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Commons; wherein is di≈øcovered the ungratefull and perfidious dealing of the ≈øaid Lord with the Parliament of England.

argument.p: [Note:] That this Commi≈øsion, together with a Letter herewith Printed concerning the ≈øame, was taken at Great-Yarmouth in the county of Norfolk, among≈øt divers other Letters and Papers directed to divers Papi≈øts in England; from one Walter Win≈øor a Papi≈øt, who brought the ≈øame from Flanders, as he confe≈ø≈øeth in his Examination, on the 26. of September, 1643. which ≈øaid Win≈øor ≈øtill remaineth in cu≈øtody.

div.head: The Commi≈øsion.
div.p:
FRancis Vander Burch, Dei & Apo≈øtolicae ≈øedis gratia Archiepi≈øcopus & Dux Cameracen, Sac. Rom. Imp. Princeps, Comes Camerace≈øii, &c. Executor & Comi≈ø≈øarius ad infra tam una cum quibu≈ødam aliis no≈øtris in hac parte Collegis per litteras Apo≈øtolicas in vim clau≈øulae & quemlibet ip≈øorum ≈øpecialiter deputatus omnibus & ≈øingulis ad quos prae≈øentes no≈øtrae litterae pervenerint, quou≈øque in fratrum tangit negotium ≈øeu tangere poterit quomedo libet in futurum, communiter vel divi≈øim quibu≈øcunque nominibus con≈øeantur, aut quacunque praefulgeant dignitate, ≈øalutem in Domino ≈øempiternam, & prae≈øentibus fidem indubiam adhibere no≈øtri≈øque,
imo verius Apo≈øtolicis obedire mandatis. Litteras Sancti in Chri≈øto Patris Domini no≈øtri, Domini Urbani divina providentia Papae Octavi, nos eum e√¢ qua decuit reverenti√¢ recepi≈ø≈øe noveritis, huju≈ømodi ≈øub tenore. Urbanus P. P. Octavus ad futuram rei memoriam Pii ‚Ä¢ . Dilecti filii Procuratoris Generalis Congregationis Angliae Ordinis Sancti Benedicti votis annuere, id ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ que ≈øpecialis gratiae favore pro≈øequi volentes & √† quibu≈øvis excommunicationts ≈øu≈øpen≈øionis & interdicti alii≈øque Eccle≈øia≈øticis ≈øententiis, cen≈øuris & panis √¢ Iure, vel ab homine qu√†vis occa≈øione vel cau≈øa latis, ≈øi quibus quomodolibet imo datus exi≈øiit ad effectum prae≈øentium duntaxat con≈øequendum harum ≈øerie ab≈øolventes & ab≈øolutum fore con≈øentes: Supplicationibus eju≈ødem Procuratoris Generalis nomine nobis ≈øuper hoc humiliter porrectis in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i de venerabilium fratrum no≈øtrorum S. R. E. Cardinalium in total Repulbica a Chri≈øtiana contra haereticam pravitatem Inqui≈øitorum generalium ab hac Sancta ≈øede Apo≈øtolicas spectaliter deputatorum con≈øilio Venerabiles fratres Archiepi≈øcopum Cameracen', ac Andomar' & Ipren' Epi≈øcopos, & quemlibet ip≈øorum Apo≈øtolica auctoritate tenore pre≈øentium ≈øubrogamus in le ‚Ä¢ um Ordinariorum in Angli ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ad effectum tantum modo auctoritate Ordinaria legitim√® in≈øtituendi Proce≈ø≈øus ≈øuper cau≈øa, & genere mortis corum qui pro fide Catholica in Anglia patiuntur, ita ut huju≈ømodi proce≈ø≈øus aliaque acta ab illis, ≈øeu quilibet ip≈øorum legitime confecta ad Doctrinas pa≈ø≈øiones, & mortes verificand ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fiant auctoritate Ordinaria. nec aliter, nec alio modo, irritum & i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ne decernentes quidquid ≈øecus ≈øuper his √† quiquam ≈øcienter, vel ignoranter contigerit attentari, Non ob≈øtantibus quatenus opus ≈øit foelicis recordationis Bonifacii Papae Octavi pradece≈ø≈øoris no≈øtri de una, & Concilii Generalis de duabus dictis, alii ‚Ä¢ que con≈øtitutionibus & Ordinationibus Apo≈øtolicis caeteri≈øque contrariis quibu≈øcunque. Datum Remae apud Sanctum Petrum ≈øub Annulo Pi≈øcatoris die vige≈øima tertia Februarii, Anni mille≈øimi ≈øexcente≈øimi quadrage≈øimi tertii, Pontificatus no≈øtri anno vig ≈øimo, ≈øignat. M: A: Maraldus.

Po≈øt quarum quidem litterarum Apo≈øtolicarum prae in≈øertarum prae≈øentationem & receptionem nobis & per nos, ut praemittitur, factas, ≈øuimus per Reverendos Dominos, Dominum Ceorgium Musket Collegii Anglicani Duaceni Prae≈øidem, fratrem Joannem
Meuti≈ø≈øe Conventus Sancti Gregorii Magni Benedictinorum Anglorum Prierem, & fratrem Angelum de Sancto Franci≈øco Provinciae fratrum Minorum in Anglia Commi≈ø≈øarium, pro parte totius Cleri ≈øecularis Anglicani Congregationi≈øque Anglicanae Ordinis Sancti Benedicti, & dictae Provinciae fratrum Minorum debita cum in≈øtantia requi≈øiti, quatenus ad earundem praein≈øertarum litterarum Apo≈øtolicarum & contentorum in ei≈ødem executionem, juxta traditas ≈øeu directas √† ≈øede Apo≈øtolica prae≈øentia per ea≈ødem litteras nobis facultatem, formam & auctoritatem procedere Littera≈øque no≈øtras de≈øuper opportunas concedere vellemus & dignaremur. Nos igitur Franci≈øcus Vander Burch, Archiepi≈øcopus & Dux Cameracen', S. R. Imp. Princeps, Comes Camerace≈ø ‚Ä¢ i, &c. Executor & Commi≈ø≈øarius ≈øubrogatus auctoritate Apo≈øtolica Prae≈øentia in locum Ordinariorum in Anglia, attendentes requi≈øitionem huju≈ømodi e≈ø≈øe ju≈øtam & nationi con≈øonam, Volente≈øque Mandatum Apo≈øtolicum ≈øupradictum nobis in hac parte directum & commi≈ø≈øum re ‚Ä¢ erenter exequi, prout tenemur: idcirco auctoritate Apo≈øtolica nobis commi≈ø≈øa, & qu√† fungimur in hac parte, tenore prae≈øentium committimus & deputamus pro iis qui Londini, vel juxta Trentam fluvium ver≈øus Londinum in Anglia degunt, Reverendos Dominos D. Georgium Gage Prothonotarium Apo≈øtolicum, P: Thomas Dade Ordinis Sancti Dominici in Doctrina Angliae Provincialem, Patrem Benedictum Coxium Congregationis Anglicanae Ordinis Sancti Benedicti Presbyterum, P: Franci≈øcum Bell Provinciae fratrum Minorum in eadem Anglia Definitorem; Pro iis qui Eboraci, vel ultra Trentam fluvium re≈øpectu civitatis Londinen≈øis in ≈øupradicta. Anglia degunt Reverendi≈ø≈øimum Dominum Philippum ≈øereni≈ø≈øimae Reginae Angliae Confe≈ø≈øarium, ac Reverendos Dominos D. Georgium Catherick, P: Robertum Hadokium, alias Ben≈øonium, Provinciae Eboracen', Ordinis Sancti Benedicti Exprovinci√†lem, ac P. Gulielmum Andertonum Ordinis Sancti Franci≈øci, Religio≈øum, lomnes ≈øimul: & conjunctim ac quemlibet corum divi≈øim ac ≈øeparatim in ≈øolidum ad effectum legitim√® in≈øtituendi Proce≈ø≈øus ≈øuper cau≈øa, & genere mortis eorum, qui in ≈øuts re≈øpective di≈øtrictibus, hac ultima ≈øaeviente contra Catholicos ibidem per≈øecutione pro fide Catholic√¢ occubuerunt, dicta auctgritate Apo≈øtolica mandantes iis ut per≈øonaliter
accedant loca, quae prepter hoc fuerint, & erunt accedenda, & evocatis coram ≈øe per≈øonis probis ac fide dignis, quae pa≈ø≈øionis ac mortis huju≈ømodi Catholicorum notitiam habuerint, de veritate pa≈ø≈øionis ac mortis corundem form√†que cau≈øis ≈øcicentiae, & circum≈øtantiis ad rem facientibus, alii≈ø
que ad rei certitudinem requi≈øitis ≈øeu alias opportunis praeviis ≈øolemni juramento diligenter interrogent, audiant, & examinent, earumque per≈øonarum nomina, cognomina, dicta & depo≈øitiones pertinenter in ≈øcriptis redigant, & ≈øic redacta & fideliter clau≈øa ad nos dirigant, ut ea po≈øtmodum ad ≈øedem Apo≈øtolicam tran≈ømittamus, quatenus de iis quod ju≈øtum fuerit ad Dei gloriam ≈øtatuat & decernat. Caeterum intendimus & declaramus quod ≈øi aliquis, vel aliqui dictorum, per nos Deputatorum, per ≈øeip≈øum vel ≈øeip≈øos, hoc munus per≈øonal√¨ter prae≈øtare non potuerit, vel non potuerint, ille vel illi quem vel quos aliquis vel aliqui dictorum Deputatorum ad dictum effectum ≈øubrogare voluerit, vel voluerint, ≈øimili omnino pote≈øtate & Iuri≈ødictione quam principales & primo Deputati gaudeat vel gaudeant quartus aliquis dictorum Deputatorum vel ab iis ≈øubrogatorum, alix legitim√® impeditis in dicto Proce≈ø≈øu in≈øtituendo cum effectu pergat & procedat, & auctoritate no≈øtra ordinaria per ≈øedem Apo≈øtolicam nobis attributa ex nunc prout tunc ip≈øis huju≈ømodi tribuimus facultatem. In quorum omnium fidem ac robur prae≈øentes per Secretarium no≈øtrum expeditas no≈øtris ≈øignatura ≈øigilloque communimus.

div.head: 5. October. 1643.
div.p:
FRancis Vander Burch, By the Grace of God, and of the Apo≈øtolicall Sea, Archbi≈øhop and Duke of Cambrey, Prince of the Sacred Romane Empire, Earl of Cambre≈øis, &c. Agent and Commi≈ø≈øary for the things hereafter mentioned. Joyntly, and ≈øeverally, with ≈øome others in that behalf, by Apo≈øtolicall Letters e≈øpecially deputed. To all and ≈øingular per≈øons, to whom our pre≈øent Letters ≈øhall come, and whom the matter herein after mentioned, doth or may concerne, joyntly and ≈øeverally, by what names ≈øoever they ≈øhall be called, or of what dignity and honour they ≈øhall be of, health everla≈øting in the Lord, to give undoubted credit to the≈øe Pre≈øents, and to obey our, or more truly the Apo≈øtolicall commands. Know ye, we did receive with that reverence which was meet, the Letters of the mo≈øt Holy Father in Chri≈øt, our Lord, the Lord Vrbane, by the Divine Providence, the Eight Pope of that name, under this Tenure, Pope Vrbane the VIII. for future remembrance of the matter: Being willing to Conde≈øcend unto the pious de≈øires of our beloved Son, the Generall Procuratour of the Congregation of England, of the order of Saint Bennet, and to favour him with a ≈øpeciall Grace (and by the Order of the≈øe Pre≈øents ab≈øolving him, and holding him to be ab≈øolved, from what≈øoever cen≈øure of Excommunication, Su≈øpen≈øion and Interdict, and all other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Cen≈øures, and Paines inflicted by Law, or by man: For what≈øoever occa≈øion or cau≈øe, if in any way, he do lye under any of them, onely for he effecting of the≈øe Pre≈øents)
Inclining unto the Petition humbly pre≈øented unto us in that behalfe, in the name of the ≈øame Generall Procurator, with the Councell of our venerable Brethren, the Cardinals of the holy Roman Church, Inqui≈øitours Generals, e≈øpecially deputed by this holy Apo≈øtolicall Sea in all the Chri≈øtan Common-wealth again≈øt Hereticall wickedne≈ø≈øe, by the tenour of the≈øe pre≈øents, and Apo≈øtolical authority we ≈øub≈øtitute our venerable Brethren the Archbi≈øhop of Cambreys the Bi≈øhops of Saint Omer and Iper, and every one of them into the place of ordinary in England only to that effect, that they may by ordinary authority according to Law make out Proce≈ø≈øe, To enquire after the cau≈øe and kinde of death of them that ≈øuffer in England for the Catholique Faith: So that ≈øuch Proce≈ø≈øe and other Acts lawfully done by them, or any of them, for the clearing of the Truth of ≈øuch ≈øufferings and deaths, be done by ordinary authority, nor otherwi≈øe, nor in any other manner; Commanding that what≈øoever in that behalfe ≈øhall happen herein to be attempted otherwi≈øe by any man, either wittingly or ignorantly, it ≈øhall be void and of none effect; Notwith≈øtanding any u≈øe that may be made of the Con≈øtitution of Pope Boniface the eight, our Predece≈ø≈øor, of mo≈øt happy memory, commonly called de una, or that of the Generall Conncell, commonly called de Duabus, or any other con≈øtitutions or Apo≈øtolicall Ordinances made to the contrary what≈øoever. Given at Rome at Saint Peters under the King of the Fi≈øher, the three and twentieth day of February 1643. in the twentieth year of Our Popedome, ≈øigned M. A. Maraldus.

After the pre≈øentation and reception of the which Apo≈øtolicall Letters above written, to Us and by Us
(as is above≈øaid made) we have been earne≈øtly and duly required by the Reverend Ma≈øter, Ma≈øter George Mu≈øher, Pre≈øident of the Engli≈øh Colledge of Dowey, Fryer Iohn Menti≈ø≈øe, Prior of the Covent of Saint Gregory the great, of the Engli≈øh Benedictins, and Frier Angell of Saint Francis, Commi≈ø≈øary of the Province of the Friers Minorites in England, on the behalfe of all the Secular Clergie of England, of the Engli≈øh congregation of the Order of Saint Bennet, and of the ≈øaid Province of the Friers Minorites, that we would be willing & vouch≈øafe to go on in the execution of the ≈øame above mentioned Apo≈øtolicall Letters, and of the contents of the ≈øame, according to the power, manner, and authority, given or ≈øent to us from the ≈øaid Apo≈øtolical Sea by the ≈øame Letters, and to grant to that end as nece≈ø≈øary Letters. We therefore Francis Vanderburgh Archbi≈øhop and Duke of Cambrey, Prince of the ≈øacred Roman Empire, Earle of Cambre≈øis, &c. Agent and commi≈ø≈øary ≈øub≈øtituted by the above-≈øaid Apo≈øtolical Authority into the place of the Ordinaries in England, taking into con≈øideration that ≈øuch a reque≈øt is ju≈øt and rea≈øonable, and willing (with reverence as we ought to do) to put in execution the above≈øaid Apo≈øtolical command directed & committed to us in that behalf. Therfore by the Apo≈øtolicall authority committed to us, & by the authority which we exerci≈øe in that behalfe; by the Tenure of the≈øe pre≈øents, we ordaine and depute for them that live at London or on this ≈øide Trent in England, the Reverend Mrs. M. George Gage, Apo≈øtolicall Prothonotary, Father Thomas Dade, Provinciall of the order of Saint Dominick, in England afore≈øaid; Father Bennet Cox, Prie≈øt of the Engli≈øh Congregation of the Order of S. Bennet, Father Francis Bell, Limitor
Collector of the Province of the Friers Minorites in England afore≈øaid; and for tho≈øe that live at York, or beyond the River of Trent in England afore≈øaid, the Reverend Mr. Phillips Confe≈ø≈øor to the mo≈øt gracious Queene of England, and the Reverend Ma≈øters, Ma≈øter George Cathericke, Father Robert Hadock, alias, Ben≈øon, late Provinciall of the Province of Yorke, of the order of S. Bennet, and Father William Anderton of the order of S. Francis; all & every one of them joyntly, ≈øeverally, and wholly to this purpo≈øe; that they according to law make pre≈ø≈øe to inquire of the cau≈øe and kinde of death of them, who in their re≈øpective Limits, during this la≈øt fierce per≈øecution there again≈øt the Catholickes, have dyed for the Catholick Faith: Commanding them by the ≈øaid Apo≈øtolicall Authority, that they do per≈øonally repaire to ≈øuch places, as for this purpo≈øe are or ≈øhall be to be repaired unto: and that they call before them, ≈øuch per≈øons of hone≈øty and credit, as have knowledge of the ≈øufferings and deaths of ≈øuch Catholicks; and that they diligently inquire, heare and examine, upon ≈øolemne oath, the truth and manner of their ≈øufferings and deaths, and the cau≈øe of ≈øuch their knowledge and ≈øuch circum≈øtances pertaining to the ≈øame and other things requi≈øite for the di≈øcovery of the truth of the matter: and that they conveniently put in writing, the names ≈øirnames, ≈øayings, and depo≈øitions of the ≈øaid per≈øons, and direct them to us, being ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, & faithfully clo≈øed up; That we may afterwards tran≈ømit them to the Apo≈øtolicall See; to the end that the ≈øaid See may ordaine and determine of them, that which ≈øhall bee fit to the glory of God. Moreover, we intend and declare, That if any one, or ≈øome of them deputed by us by him≈øelfe, or by them≈øelves, cannot
per≈øonally performe that office, he or they, whom, one or ≈øome of the ≈øaid deputed per≈øons ≈øhall or will ≈øub≈øtitute to that effect; he or they ≈øo ≈øub≈øtituted, ≈øhall enjoy the very like power & juri≈ødiction, as they which were principally and fir≈øt deputed doe enjoy: To that end, that any one of the ≈øaid deputies or their ≈øub≈øtitutes, the re≈øt having lawfull excu≈øe of ab≈øence, may proceed and go on with effect in the execution of the≈øe pre≈øents, and by our ordinary authority given unto us by the Apo≈øtolicall See from this time forth wee grant unto them ≈øuch power; for te≈øtimony and credit whereof we have authorized with our hand and ≈øeale the≈øe pre≈øents: Di≈øpatched by our Secretary.
div.closer:
Given at Cambrey in our Archiepi≈øcopall Palace in the yeare of our Lord 1643. Tenth of June
FRANCIS VANDER BURGH, Archbi≈øhop of Cambrey,
By the command of the mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious and Reverend Lord, the Lord Archbi≈øhop and Duke of Cambrey afore≈øaid. Foulin Secretary.

argument.p: This Figure of a Cro≈ø≈øe ‚úö was on the top of the Letter.

div.p: SEEing that I was to write unto you obout the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe contained in the inclo≈øed Commi≈ø≈øion; I was al≈øo commanded by my Ma≈øter (who is altogether unknown unto you) to let you under≈øtand, that the Bearer (who is the Foreman of his ≈øhop) is ≈øent to the party with Letters from Mr. Iozelin (the which he is to impart unto you) and with Letters from him≈øelfe, to the Parents of ≈øome young men, who are Prenti≈øes here; expecting to heare their re≈øolutions before they can become Free men. I hope that you will find him to be a fit man for both imployments (if you would be plea≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him with the be≈øt advice whiles he is a ≈øtranger among≈øt you) peradventure you will ≈øtartle at the ≈øight of the inclo≈øed Commi≈ø≈øion, con≈øidering how the times go now in tho≈øe parts, and to how little purpo≈øe it is to medle in affairs of that nature. But if you plea≈øe to know the true rea≈øons and motives why I ≈øent it now, I doubt not but that you will re≈øt ≈øatisfied. The fir≈øt is becau≈øe I had now an extraordinary good opportunity to ≈øend it ≈øafely by a known friend, who would have a ≈øpecial care to ≈øee it conveighed unto you, with tho≈øe ≈ømall directions it hath; which none could make any u≈øe of, (in ca≈øe it ≈øhould fall into their hands) but only the Bearer: and if I ≈øhould not have ≈øent it now by him, the directions mu≈øt have beene ≈øuch as might have brought you into ≈øome que≈øtion, if my Letters had been intercepted.

The ≈øecond and principall rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the Pope
is old and ≈øickly, and ≈øo is the Archbi≈øhop of Cambrey, and if either of them dye before the mattet be begun by one or other, the grace would be of no force: and if any of the three named in it do but call any one Catholike man and take ≈øuch information as hee can give of the martyrdome of Father Ambro≈øe, and record them before witne≈ø≈øe, the grace will be of ≈øuch force that wee may make u≈øe of it, any time the≈øe thirty or forty years following, when the ≈øaid parties are dead. Therefore I be≈øeech you excu≈øe me for having ≈øent it unto you: and for Gods ≈øake commend it pre≈øently to ≈øome of the parties named in it, or to be named by them, to ≈øee the matter begun, as I have ≈øaid, and then to be kept in great ≈øecrecy till we ≈øee better times.

closer.salute: Thus in ha≈øte I bid you fare-well.

argument.p: This Letter was intercepted with the former Commi≈ø≈øion, with divers other Letters to Papi≈øts in England.

div.head: A CATALOGVE OF The Vicars Generall and Arch-Deacons in ENGLAND, under the Bi≈øhop of CALCEDON.

div.head: The new divi≈øion of the Provinces, of the Vicaries and of the Archdeacons, with the number of the Archdeaconries, contained in every one of the Vicar≈øhips.
div.p: 1. The fir≈øt Vicar≈øhip containes ≈øeaven Counties or Provinces, viz. Cornwall, Devon≈øhire, Somer≈øet≈øhire, Wilt≈øhire, Glouce≈øter≈øhire, Hamp≈øhire, and it hath under it, three Archdeaconries.

2. The ≈øecond Vicariate containes ≈øeven Counties, Viz. Midle≈øex with the City of London and City of VVe≈øtmin≈øter, Kent, Su≈øsex, Surrey, Barke≈øhire, E≈øsex, and Hartford≈øhire, and it hath foure Archdeaconries,
1. London Middle≈øex
2. Surrey Barke≈øhire
3. Kent Su≈ø≈øex
4. E≈øsex and Hartford

3. The third Vicariate containes five Counties, viz. Bedford≈øhire, Huntington≈øhire, Cambridge≈øhire with the I≈øle of Ely and with the part of the Province of Lincoln≈øhire which is called Holland and Norfolke and out of that part which is called Mar≈øhland and Suffolke; And it hath three Archdeaconries.

list.item: 3. CaÃÑbridge with the I≈øle of Ely, Holland, & Mar≈øhland.

div.p:
4. The fourth Vicariate containes eight Counties,
viz. Oxford, Buckingham, Northampton, Leice≈øter, Stafford, Warwicke, worce≈øter and Che≈øter, and hath foure Arch-deaconries.
5. The fifth Vicariate containes fiveteen Counties, viz. North-Wales, South-VVales with the I≈øle of Angle≈øey, Hartford, and Shrop≈øhire, and it hath three Archdeaconries.
1. North-Wales with the I≈øle of Angle≈øey, Mountgomerie, Merioneth, Denbigh, Flint, Carnarvan.
2. Monmouth, Clamorgan, Radnar, Cardigan, Carmar. then, and Pembrooke.
3. Hereford and Shrop≈øhire.
6. The ≈øixth Vicariate containes five Counties, viz.
7. The ≈øeaventh Vicariate containes five Counties Lanca≈øhire, We≈øtmerland, Cumberland, Northumberland, and the Bi≈øhopricke of Durham, and it hath three Arch. deaconries.

According to the pre≈øent divi≈øion there are ≈øeaven Vicar≈øhips and three and twenty Archdeaconries, viz. Two more then there were heretofore ordained. That if it
doth not ≈øeeme good to multiply the number of the Archdeacons, the pre≈øent divi≈øion may be ≈øo ordained that Che≈øhire and Stafford≈øhire ≈øhall be taken from the fourth Vicar≈øhip, and the Archdeanerie of Worce≈øter, and Warwicke≈øhire, ≈øhall be added thereunto, and Che≈øhire ≈øhall be ioyned to the Archdeanerie of North-Wales or Lanca≈øhire, and ≈øo ≈øhall belong to the fifth or ≈øeaventh Vicar≈øhip.

argument.p: A Committee of Parliament ≈øitting at Roche≈øter, intercepted the fore≈øaid Catalogue and divers other letters and papers herewith printed, as they were carrying to the Bi≈øhop of Chalcedon, for the nominating ≈øuch per≈øons to fill up vacant places in England as his Lord≈øhip ≈øhall thinke fit.

div.p: I Send you all the inclo≈øed open, that ere you deliver them to my Lord, you may if you plea≈øe take Copies of them, or at lea≈øt be able to ≈øugge≈øt unto his Lord≈øhip the ordering of his Secretary to copy out, and keepe ≈øafe ≈øuch Records as we are in danger here to lo≈øe, and cannot mi≈ø≈øe without great prejudice to our Clergy.

You have herein what light and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance we can give you towards filling up the Chapter, in ca≈øe you per≈øi≈øt in that re≈øolution in the≈øe confu≈øed times, which perhaps con≈øidering my Lords age were not ami≈ø≈øe to di≈øpatch, if not before, at lea≈øt as ≈øoone after the election of a Coadjutor as may be, le≈øt his Lord≈øhip die before it be done, for we were better have it done le≈ø≈øe compleatly before his Lord≈øhips death then not at all, and this cogitation hath accurred ≈øince I writ the former Papers, wherein was ≈øome doubt made about the point, e≈øpecially in the long Letter I had written to you before this ≈øetting downe the pre≈øent ≈øtate of your Chapter, and certifying who are living thereof, who Dead, wherein are ≈øome things nece≈ø≈øary perhaps to ≈øhew my Lord what ere the whole Letter it ≈øelfe be, which I referre unto your di≈øcretion, becau≈øe I had no notice from his Lord≈øhip of filling up all the vacant Places in the Chapter, only of adding ≈øome more Canons thereunto.

As I had written thus farre, I received yours of this weeke, and by good fortune Ma≈øter Herbert was actually with Ma≈øter Web≈øter at the ≈øame time; ≈øo after he had read your Letter to him, and heard how earne≈øtly Mr. Web≈øter moved not to re≈øi≈øt his Brethrens Election, in ca≈øe your ≈øelfe may not comply with the place, hee at la≈øt con≈øented to ≈øubmit to what his Brethren ≈øhould finally conclude upon, de≈øiring fir≈øt, that they advi≈øe againe about your ≈øelfe, if there be any probabilitie with you to comply with the Place, if not, you ≈øee by his con≈øent our bu≈øine≈ø≈øe is at an end, for he hath (in ca≈øe you faile) all the Votes there, and here of tho≈øe that are to Vote herein; as al≈øo he hath Ma≈øter Ben≈øons of Doway, and doubtle≈ø≈øe will have mo≈øt, if not all, of our Brethren in the Countries, who are not yet con≈øulted about this affaire, but ≈øhall be ≈øpeedily.

The ≈øaid News of Mr. Montague being taken at Rochester,
Mr. Montague and
preparation for him in the Tower doth much afflict his friend ‚Ä¢ and will be as unwelcome to you, as to any man living. This night the Count de Harecourt is expected in Towne; I be≈øeech you excu≈øe me at this time to Ma≈øter Clifton, you ≈øee I have been overcharged with the inclo≈øed, and pray tell my Lord I had not time to write faire tho≈øe Lights I ≈øend him for „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Chapter be≈øides they are not ≈øo perfect as were requi≈øite if we had more time, but if his Lord≈øhip will give longer time, he ≈øhall have it more exact. The ninth Canon now I perceive was Ma≈øter Herbert; excu≈øe, if what I writ before in that be ob≈øcure or le≈ø≈øe exact, for I have no time to rectifie it, you may ea≈øily mend all Errours therein by what is written otherwi≈øe about this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the Chapter.

ACcording to your de≈øire, and my promi≈øe, I now ≈øend you the ≈øtate of our pre≈øent Chapter, together with ≈øuch Patents as will be nece≈ø≈øary for the filling up thereof, with a particular of how many thereof are dead, and with ≈øuch a note (as up on ≈øo ≈øhort a warning could be gotten) of names to fill it up againe, as have been by tho≈øe of the Chapter in London reflected on, for ≈øuch was your de≈øire.

The Copies of the Patents are ≈øuch as Ma≈øter Lovell left me, and I ≈ønall de≈øire that you will cau≈øe them to be kept there in ≈øafetie, le≈øt tho≈øe I have here ≈øhould in the≈øe trouble≈øome times mi≈øcarry. I could wi≈øh you had al≈øo there other Copies of things mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, which I find here hand≈øomely recorded in Bookes by Ma≈øter Lovell, God re≈øt his ≈øoule; but truly I am ≈øo ill, I cannot my ≈øelfe tran≈øcribe them, and to tru≈øt them out of my hands in the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ times to Scribes, I dare not, and ≈øpare the Booke I cannot, ≈øo I mu≈øt hope God will protect them and us his ≈øervants, whom they concerne.

You will perceive by the Copie of the Catalogues of Vicars and Archdeacons which Ma≈øter Lovell left, as I now ≈øend them to you tran≈øcribed, that there have bin two divi≈øions of the Counties, in the fir≈øt there appeare 55. in the la≈øt but 53, Counties of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
di≈øtributed unto the care of 7. Vicars Generall, and of 23. Archdeacons out of which number of Archdeacons you mu≈øt deduct but 7. fora≈ømuch as the 7. Vicars Generall not being (as Vicars) of the Chapter were made each of them Archdeacons purpo≈øely to render them Chapter men al≈øo, ≈øo that how are the number of Archdeacons be 23. yet deducting 7. out of that number, as appropriate to the 7. Vicars you will find remaining only 16. Archdeacons, I meane ≈øuch as are purely Archdeacons, and not Vicars to boote; And yet by the Note of Ma≈øter Lovells at the end of the new Divi≈øion, me thinkes there was an intention to have only 22. Archdeacons in all, or to ≈øpeake perhaps more properly to the Bi≈øhops intention, but 22. Chapter-men. Yet I find that either you mu≈øt increa≈øe the former di≈øtricts of ≈øome Archdeacons, of el≈øe you will not exhau≈øt the Counties in the di≈øtribution thereof, for you ≈øhall not find the Counties of Nottingham nor Darby appropriated to any Archdeacon, unle≈ø≈øe you re≈øolve the number of 23. ≈øhall ≈øtand good. An perhaps that number was reduced to 22. only in the la≈øt Divi≈øion upon reflection that the ≈øeventh Vicar viz. Ma≈øter Norton was not made Archdeacon, that I can find upon any Record, and I ≈øend you all I have of this nature, ≈øo that my Lord and you of the Chapter there, mu≈øt plea≈øe to re≈øolve whether there ≈øhall be any Vicar Generall without the Title of Archdeacon, and ≈øo let the fir≈øt number of 23. Archdeacons ≈øtand good, or whether all the ≈øeven Vicars ≈øhall be Archdeacons, and then the la≈øt Divi≈øion of Archdeacons into 22. to remaine. It ≈øeemes here mo≈øt con≈øonant to rea≈øon, to make each Vicar Generall an Archdeacon, but what you there re≈øolve will be here allowed of, but you ≈øhall doe well to appropriate ≈øuch Counties to each Vicar and Archdeacon, as may be mo≈øt convenient for them to repaire unto, which will be ahard matter to determine in the≈øe un≈øetled times.

And hence you will perceive that by the Addition of Canons to the Chapter, which you know were added but lately, that without filling up the places of the old Chapter-men decea≈øed, you will have as great a number almo≈øt of Chapter men now living to choo≈øe a Coadjutor to the Deane (which is the pre≈øent affaire in agitation) as would have been if all the dead per≈øons vacant places were filled up before the Election of this Coadjutor, ≈øo that if
the de≈øire of filling the Chapter proceed out of a feare that there will want a competent number of Chapter-men to make this Election, con≈øidering the late Addition of Canons to the Chapter with power of voting in all affaires of the Clergy, there will be no want of almo≈øt as full a number as ever were of the Chapter ≈øince it was fir≈øt erected.

For you ≈øee there never were above two or three and twenty at mo≈øt of the Chapter, and albeit mo≈øt of them that were Vicars and Archdeacons be dead; neverthele≈ø≈øe tho≈øe that are living together with the Canons lately added thereunto, amount to the number of twentie, as I wrote you word la≈øt weeke; onely I forgot then to tell you, that one of the ≈øix whom I reckoned upon to be in Paris, viz. Ma≈øter Laborne, is neither of the Chapter in vertue of Vicar, Archdeacon, or Canon, that I can find upon any Record, but this I impute to an Accident of his being out of the way at Tame when the Canons were made, and ≈øo I reckon upon him as if he were a Chapter-man, the rather becau≈øe he was, and is ≈øtill one of his Lord≈øhips Con≈øult, which may perhaps ip≈øo facto, give him that quality,The whole Chapter in the nature of a Coun≈øell to Doctor Rich. Smith titular Bi≈øhop of Chalcedon and Ordinarie of England and Scotland by Commi≈ø≈øion from the Pope. in regard the whole Chapter hath the nature of his Lord≈øhips Coun≈øell.

But now to come unto the particulars, who are dead of the Chapter, and who now living thereof, that ≈øo you may ≈øee cleerely in the particulars what I tell you of our Chapter in generall, you may plea≈øe to under≈øtand, that of the Vicars Generall who were at mo≈øt in number but ≈øeven, there are five dead, viz. Ma≈øter Colleton, Mr. Bennet, Mr. Bo≈øwill, Mr. Broughton, Mr. Norton, ≈øo that you mu≈øt thinke of Con≈øtituting five Vicars, for however Ma≈øter Mu≈øcot was made coadjutor to Ma≈øter Colleton, yet he is now in a charge by the Popes command incompatible with that office of Vicar Generall in Ma≈øter Broughtons place, who≈øe re≈øidence he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth, yet I doe not conceive that hee was ever made Vicar Generall by Patent.

Now for the Vicars actually living, you will ea≈øily ≈øee they are but two, viz. Ma≈øter Iack≈øon, and Ma≈øter Trollop, who had need of a Coadjutor, being him≈øelf grown unable to travell as you all know,

As for the Archdeacons, there are dead five in the five Vicars, and of ≈øuch as were purely Archdeacons and no more, there are
dead be≈øides Ma≈øter Mu≈øcot (who≈øe place is vacant though he bee living) ten, viz. Ma≈øter Pits, Doctor Wright and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor Brabant, Ma≈øter Strickland, Ma≈øter Heines and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor Doctor Lovell, Ma≈øter Hanmer and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor Mr. Guin, as al≈øo the intended ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to him, Ma≈øter Robert Hughes lately, Doctor Britton, Ma≈øter More, Ma≈øter Martine, Mr. Tushenor and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor Mr. A≈øton, and Mr. Worthington.

I doe not accompt Mr. Shellyes, nor Mr. Merricks places vacant, by rea≈øon Mr. Lane and Mr. Hide (≈øurviving both) doe ≈øupply them, but whether by Patents created Archdeacons or not I cannot ≈øay, or whether by Deputation only they execute the ≈øame, which in effect I account is all one.
So that here are undoubtedly to be de novo, created ten Archdeacons to fill up the places vacant by death, and more to ≈øupply Mr. Mu≈øcots place yet living as above≈øaid.

Now for the living Archdeacons they are in number two, in the two Vicars above, and foure that are purely Archdeacons by Patents undoubted, viz. Ma≈øter Redman, Ma≈øter Button, Mr. Hughes, and Ma≈øter Manger, whereunto if you adde the ≈øuppliants (at lea≈øt) living, Ma≈øter Hide and Ma≈øter Lane, then are there ≈øix Archdeacons living.

As for Canons there were Created (as I remember) nine at the fir≈øt, and they are all living ≈øtill, viz. Ma≈øter Blaclo, Ma≈øter Harrington, Ma≈øter Holden, Mr. Fitton, Ma≈øter Clifford, Ma≈øter Morgan, Ma≈øter Curtes, Ma≈øter Gage, and Mr. Herbert; for I have now no convenience to come at ≈øuch Records as doe ≈øhew this, perhaps your memory will tell you this better then mine, or el≈øe then Ma≈øter Hide was made Canon, and not Ma≈øter of which you ≈øhall know the certaintie ere long; but however thus you ≈øee what with two Vicars living, ≈øix Archdeacons, and nine Canons, and the Deane, there are eighteen per≈øons of the Chapter now living; or take the Deane and at lea≈øt five Archdeacons, and nine pure Canons, ≈øuppo≈øing Ma≈øter Hide to be no Archdeacon, they will in all amount to the number of ≈øeventeen per≈øons, whereunto adding the three Suppliants for Archdeacons, who have as vet never had Patents viz, Ma≈øter Barlo in Warwick≈øhire, and Ma≈øter Stevens in Hertford, and Ma≈øter Thomas Greene in Suffolke, by the
old Divi≈øion Norff. by new; you ≈øee we may accompt upon ju≈øt nineteene or twenty Chapter-men now actually living, whereas at fir≈øt Erection of the Chapter there were never more (as you ≈øee) then twenty two or twenty three at mo≈øt: And thus you have the exact account of the Chapter as now it ≈øtands, wherewith if you re≈øt not ≈øatisfied, but de≈øire either to make more Canons (as my Lord ≈øeemes to doe) or to fill up the number of tho≈øe that ale dead, Wee can ≈øugge≈øt unto you for the pre≈øent only the≈øe that follow for that purpo≈øe, becau≈øe we cannot have an exact accompt from all the Shires what men are now re≈øiding therein, much le≈ø≈øe can we make any probable conjecture how to ≈øix any one man in any one County of England, as times now ≈øtand, to officiate therein, and ≈øo we ≈øhould not at this time have thought of filling up the vacant places yet becau≈øe you there have that cogitation, and de≈øire to know whom we here in towne thinke fitting for that purpo≈øe, wee have reflected on the≈øe under-written.
For Vicars Generall.
Ma≈øter Blaclo Mr. Holden, Mr. Harrington, Mr. Fitton, Mr. Herbert, Mr. Hide, Mr. Drury Mr. Clifford, Mr. Laborne, Mr. Barquer.
For Archdeacons.

Ma≈øter Iohn Berrington, Mr. Stevens, Mr. Barlo, Mr. Edward Hughes. Mr Green, Mr. Coffin, Mr. Sands, Mr. Laurence, Mr. Bruarton, Doctor Bloud≈øton, Mr. Faulconer, Mr. Ireland, Mr. Iennings, Mr. Curtes, Mr. Cattericke, Mr. Clampit, Mr. Woodward, Ma≈øter Cheake.
For Canons.

Ma≈øter Carleton, Mr. Everard, Mr. More, Mr. Knightley, Ma≈øter Warham Mr. Polewheele, Mr. Carre, Mr. Todhill, Mr. Brad≈øhawe, La≈ø≈øels, Mr. Warnford, Mr. Hall, Mr. Worthington, Mr. Marten, Mr. Lutlo, Mr. Turbervile, Mr. Ellice, Mr. Weekes, Mr. Harri≈øon, Mr. Page, Mr. Skinner, Mr. Sale, Mr. Totty, Mr. Tu≈øtall.

Above all things you mu≈øt recommend ≈øecrecie if you re≈øolve upon Ma≈øter Herbert, that his Lady come not to the notice of his being cho≈øen into any Office that will require re≈øort to him, or his going abroad.

Ma≈øter Carre however not in England, is a man ≈øo con≈øiderable, that above all others not already of the Chapter, it were fit he were made one thereof, and however I put him among≈øt Canons only, yet if his continuall ab≈øence admit of higher place, ≈øurely his merrits will claime it.

div.head: CONSIDERATIONS.
div.p: COn≈øiderations about filling up the Chapter.
The maine to appoint ≈øuch Officers in ≈øuch Divi≈øions, as probably ≈øhall re≈øide therein, or at lea≈øt conveniently may once a yeare repaire thereto to comply with their Officers.
Then per≈øi≈øting in the la≈øt Divi≈øion, which you will find taken out of Ma≈øter Records.
The fir≈øt Vicar is Ma≈øter Hammon in Cornwall.

Note that he is al≈øo Archdeacon of the Shires, Hunt. and Wilt≈øhire; now to keep the forme of this la≈øt Divi≈øion, you mu≈øt either adde Glouce≈øter ≈øhire to his Archdeaconate, or el≈øe incurre a greater confu≈øion in altering the whole frame of this Divi≈øion.

And here I may not omit to let you know, that ma≈øter Ham. hath often de≈øired to re≈øigne up his Archdeaconate in the two Shires above ≈øaid, for what cau≈øe I know not; but admit hee may be intreated to keepe them, and to accept of Gloce≈øter ≈øhire thereunto;
Yet you mu≈øt ca≈øt for two Archdeacons more, viz. of Somer≈øet, Dor≈øet. Cornwall and Devon.

For however ma≈øter Manger is living Archdeacon of Somer≈øet and Dor≈øet ≈øhire yet now a bedrid man in Wales, hee had need of a Coadjutor at lea≈øt. The men living in, or at lea≈øt acquainted, & frequenting tho≈øe parts are,
Ma≈øter Victor, Mr. Martine, Mr. Woodward, the two Brothers Warhams, Mr. White Mr. Hames, Mr. Browne, Mr. Newman.

The ≈øaid Vicar according to this la≈øt Divi≈øion, of London, Etcae't; will be the man of mo≈øt con≈øideration in this affaire, as being (being neere to the Dean) hee through who≈øe hands the greate≈øt part of the Clergies affaires will run, both for receiving the Prie≈øts new commers,
and dealing With Per≈øons of greato≈øt ranke about the Towne. This was Mr. Lahetans charge, and ≈øince Mr. Mu≈øcots, and is now (by his ab≈øence, and being in a charge incompatible therewith) vacant.

If you thinke of fixing in this place any of the Chapter-men now about the Towne, you will finde few to afford you choyce, for Mr. Herbert is already ≈øuppliant to the ≈øixth Vicariate, and happily may bee changed into the fifth, as being the onely Britton that we can thinke of except Ma≈øter Humphrey Hughes, to be Vicar Generall of Wales Etcae't, Mr. Hamman you ≈øee is already fixed, Mr. Web≈øter is Deane, here onely remaine of Chapter-men Mr. Curtes, and Mr. Hoard now about the Towne. ≈øo that you mu≈øt in this point goe I believe by ghe≈ø≈øe who is likely of all tho≈øe learned and grave Chaptermen now at Paris or Doway to fixe in Towne when times come favourable, and tho≈øe men you know are Ma≈øter Blacklo, Mr. Harrington, Mr. Barquer Mr. Holden, Mr. Filton, Mr. Hide, Mr. Clifford, Mr. Laborne, Ma≈øter Drury.
Now admit you fixe upon one of the≈øe abroad, for the Vicar Generall about London;

You are then to finde him three Archdeacons more, for by this la≈øt divi≈øion there are foure Archdeacons belonging to this Vicurate, ≈øo that making the Vicar one of the≈øe foure Archdeacons, as is ≈øuppo≈øed you will, there remaine three Archdeacons to be cho≈øen under him.
With whom they ≈øhall be mo≈øt ≈øerviceable for the c√≥mon good, as being mo≈øt upon the eye of the world, and ≈øtay of our common affaires, you mu≈øt re≈øolve.
The Prie≈øts about the towne are now ≈øo few, that they ≈øcarce make a number, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are Chapter-men, and not already deputed otherwaies, viz. Ma≈øter Curles Mr. Howard.

The Prie≈øts abroad you know. The Prie≈øts (not Chaptermen) in towne to bee thought on for this charge are ≈øew or none, onely Mr. Worthington, though hee was one moved to bee made of the Chapter, and it was refu≈øed, becau≈øe hee was as ≈øervant to Doway being Procurator, and ≈øo not to governe.

Note, that of the three Archdeacons, Ma≈øter Lane mu≈øt bee one, for he hath a long time ≈øupplyed Mr. Theli ‚Ä¢ s place as Archdeacon of Su≈ø≈øex, and ≈øo to keep Order of this ≈øecond Divi≈øion, mu≈øt have added unto his di≈øtrict
Kent al≈øo; ≈øo his Patent mu≈øt run Archdeacon of Su≈ø≈øex and Kent.
The third Vicar of Bedford, Huntington Elect, is in vertue already, and in repute, M. Herbert, and con≈øequently Archdeacon of two Counties therunto beloÃÑging.

So then you mu≈øt provide for him two Archdeacons more out of the≈øe Prie≈øts following (you will take ≈øuch as live in tho≈øe parts) they are Ma≈øter Thomas Greene, Mr. Weekes, Mr. Everard, Mr. Carleton, Mr. Henry Blacklo.
In Cambridge elect, Elie, Hoh, Marchland, or thereabouts, none at all.

The fourth Vicar of Oxford Buckingham. Elect, which was Doctor Bo≈øvile, and now mu≈øt be ≈øupplyed by whom you think good, either of tho≈øe named in an other paper for Vicars, or of ≈øome of the≈øe following Prie≈øts living in that Divi≈øion and hath under him foure Archdeacons, but him≈øelfe being to be one of the foure, you mu≈øt ca≈øt for three more, and if you take the Prie≈øts living in tho≈øe Counties they are the≈øe that follow.
Ma≈øter, Button Archdeacon already of Stafford and Che≈øhire, but ≈øo old, that he had need of a Coadjutor, with power to ≈øucceed him.

Ma≈øter Barlo, Mr. Bruerton, Mr. Venables, Mr. Lawrence, Ma≈øter Suttlo, Mr. Turbervill, Ma≈øter Iennings, de≈øigned one for a Reader, a very able man, but young; Ma≈øter Humphrey Hattlo, Mr. William Ellis.
The≈øe are in Worce≈øter Warwick Stafford, Che≈øhire: in Northton & Leice≈øter ≈øhire are Mr. Faulconer, Mr. Cheeke, Mr. Edward Hughes.
Oxford and Bucks are the Counties perhaps mo≈øt fit for the≈øe Vicars di≈øtrict as hee is Archdeacon.
The fi≈øt Vicar, who is he of Wells Elect, hath under him three onely Archdeacons, whereof him≈øelfe ≈øtanding for one, you are to thinke onely of two Archdeacons more for that Divi≈øion.
For the Vicar him≈øelfe there occurres none fitter then either Mr. Herbert, (if he be not deputed Vicar in Huntington Elect) or Mr. Humphrey Hughes now Archdeacon of North-Wales.
For two Archdeacons under him, be≈øides, if you choo≈øe them out of Prie≈øts in tho≈øe parts, they are the≈øe following.

Ma≈øter Stevens living in Hertford,
Mr. Vaughan, Mr. Stephen Pue, Mr. Permane, Mr. Williams, Mr. Iohn Barrington, Ma≈øter Iohn Powell, Mr. Perkins, Mr. Thomas Street, Mr. Iohn Holland Remble, Ma≈øter Barnes Lay, Mr. William Pue, Mr. Francis Greene, chiefe man, Ma≈øter Elliets, Mr. Morris, Mr. Pri≈øes, two of them.
Ma≈øter Stevens and Mr. Barrington held the two fitte≈øt.

The ≈øixth Vicar, who is of Yorke, Darby, Nottingham, Lincolne, and Rutland, and who≈øe place is vacant, hath under him only two Archdeacons, whereof him≈øelfe being one, you are to thinke of one more onely for that Divi≈øion.
The men fit to be thought on for this Vicariate, if you take the Prie≈øts living in tho≈øe parts are, Ma≈øter Falconer, Mr. Coffine.

The Archdeacon may bee one of tho≈øe names in the foure Vicars di≈øtrict, Mr. French, Mr. Arnold, Mr. Fathering, Mr. Edward Hughes, Mr. Iack≈øon, Mr. Wor
‚Ä¢ hington.

The ≈øeventh Vicar who is hee ‚Ä¢ of Lanca≈øhire, Northumberland, &c. Ma≈øter Trollop ≈øtill living, but ≈øo old, as he had need of a Coadjutor with power to ≈øucceed him, which whether it may not be Mr. Holden con≈øidering who is of tho≈øe parts, or ma≈øter Lab. who is likewi≈øe of the ≈øame you may there advi≈øe.
This Vicar hath under him three Archdeacons, him≈øelfe being one; you are to appoint one more onely, Mr. Redman being Archdeacon in Lanca≈øhire already.
The Prie≈øts in the Countrey mo≈øt con≈øiderable, for Vicars or Archdeacons, are the≈øe that follow.
In Northumberland and the York-≈øhire di≈øtrict.

Mr. Catricke, Mr. Walker, Doctor Blunder≈øton, Ma≈øter Wivell, Mr. Nearby, Mr. Iohn La≈ø≈øells, Ma≈øter H. Greene, Mr. William Con≈øtable, Mr. Hodge≈øon, Ma≈øter Strickland; one his name Prebend of Yorke Min≈øter.
In Lanca≈øhire, there is already Archdeacons, Ma≈øter Redman; too be≈øides him are, Ma≈øter Sands principally, Mr. Totty, Mr. Sale, Mr. Thomas Worthington, Ma≈øter Tunstall.

opener.salute: Right Reverend my very good Lord,

div.p: I≈øend you now according to my promi≈øe la≈øt week ≈øuch Copies of Patents as you de≈øired of Canons; and ≈øuch other of Vicars and Archdeacons, and Rurall Deanes as you may have need of for compleating the Chapter with ≈øuch light into that affaire as in the≈øe darke and confu≈øed times I could procure.

I mu≈øt not omit to certifie your Lord≈øhip, that I have in≈øerted Mr. Peter Warnefords name among≈øt tho≈øe who are ≈øugge≈øted here to be made Canons, and I ≈øhould humbly de≈øire he may be made ≈øuch for one maine rea≈øon above others, that I have a probable hope hereby to ≈øecure the Chapter of the holy Thorne after his decea≈øe: and that is a Jewell which I am ≈øure your Lord≈øhip values at a high rate,A pretious Relique. as al≈øo doe all others that know thereof.

If the light I have given in the choice of ≈øuch men as may compleat the Chapter be ≈øufficient to ≈øatisfy your Lord≈øhip of the merits of the men ≈øugge≈øted: Perhaps it may not be a mi≈ø≈øe to thinke of even in the≈øe uncertaine times, if for no other rea≈øon then to prevent mortality, and that the Chapter might have the fuller power in its compleatne≈ø≈øe in ca≈øe your Lord≈øhip ≈øhould dy; as we that are many yeares younger cannot ≈øay but wee may dye very ≈øuddenly, and truly but for this only rea≈øon perhaps it were better deferre the filling up the Chapter till wee better times expected; yet ≈øince I writ tho≈øe inclo≈øed Papers I have reflected that perhaps it may not bee ami≈ø≈øe to compleat the Chapter with all ≈øpeed that may be, for however we cannot ≈øugge≈øt unto your Lord≈øhip all our men in every County, yet I am confident we have named tho≈øe that are fitte≈øt for ≈øuch places in each County, and ≈øuch as are per≈øoually be≈øt known I beleive to your Lord≈øhip for the mo≈øt part of them.

As I wrote la≈øt weeke that Mr. Fittons repaire to England would not be nece≈ø≈øary though he be cho≈øen Coadjutor to Mr. Web≈øter, cum jure mi≈ø≈øionis, ≈øo I write againe now upon better grounds, for God be thanked Mr. Web≈øter mends in his health: but admit he ≈øhould fall back and dy, yet even in that ca≈øe perhaps Mr. Fitton would mo≈øt probably get our Chapter confirmed in his per≈øon of Deane, and this not onely through his being
knowne and liked well of in Rome, but farther through his perticular relation with Lord _____ who perhaps would conduce much towards confirming our Chapter, and Mr. Fittons per≈øon and the Confirmation of our Chap: being the main thing we ayme at, moves many to thinke, that we were better choo≈øe Mr. Fitton Coadjutor then a ≈øtronger man; becau≈øe if in his per≈øon we get the Chapter confirmed, we can ea≈øily choo≈øe a Coadjutor to him in ca≈øe he ≈øhould not grow ≈øtrong; And ≈øo by this means we effect our greate≈øt affaire and de≈øire. The re≈øt is that I am, my Lord,

argument.p: Mr. Herbert upon ≈øight of the≈øe la≈øt Letters from being moved by Mr. Web≈øter to accept of the place makes an≈øwer, that if Mr. Fitton cannot ≈øupply the place, rather then give offence unto his Brethren, he is content to conforme to the Votes of his Brethren.

div.head: A Letter from the Earl of Warwick, and ≈øome Members of the hou≈øe of COMMONS: To the Honorable, William Lenthall E≈øquire; Speaker of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe.
div.p: VVE have thought fit to acquaint you with ≈øome Informations that we have lately received, concerning the affairs of Ireland, ≈øuch as we ≈øuppo≈øe you will think fit to be imparted to the Hou≈øe. The Inhabitants of the Lath of Saint Augu≈øtine in the county of Kent, out of their charitable commi≈øeration of the mi≈øeries of the Prote≈øtants in Ireland, (being inabled thereunto by an Ordinance of Parliament). did in a very large manner contribute and gather Five hundred quartets of Wheat, and other Grain; and accordingly ≈øent it over to Cork, imbarqued in a Ve≈ø≈øell called the Pro≈øperous of Sandwich, whereof one Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet was Ma≈øter; who accordingly carried the ≈øame unto Cork, and delivered it unto the hands of the Lord Inchequine, according to an Order of the Committee for Iri≈øh affairs: Now the ≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øell being returned, the Ma≈øter thereof makes this report, which we with all care and diligence have ≈øent up.

1. Fir≈øt, That the Lord Inchequine was ≈øo far from di≈øtributing the ≈øaid Grain, according to the intention of the Parliament, and the Doners, (who did intend it as a free Gift, for the relief of the poor Prote≈øtants in Ireland) that he did ≈øeize it, and ≈øell it at a very dear rate, to any that would buy it, detaining it from tho≈øe to whom it was given.

2. That he did not onely deprive them of the intended Charity, but al≈øo oppre≈øt them, with Billetting of two Regiments of Souldiers, that are ≈øince ≈øent over, (whereof the ≈øaid Mr. Ba≈ø≈øet was an eye-witne≈ø≈øe) under the command of Sir Charles Vava≈øour, and Sir John Pawlet, to the Port of Bri≈øtoll, to ≈øerve here again≈øt the Parliament.

3. That the Lord Inchequine did pre≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid Ma≈øter, Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet, to carry over more Souldiers to the Port of Bri≈øtoll, which Ba≈ø≈øet did colourably undertake, and attended ≈øeverall dayes to receive the Souldiers aboard of him, till ≈øuch time as he met with a convenient opportunity to make his e≈øcape, which he de≈øired, and now at la≈øt obtained.

4. The ≈øaid Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet doth report upon very good grounds, That there are further intentions of rai≈øing great Forces of the Iri≈øh Rebells, to come over to ≈øerve again≈øt the Parliament; and that for pre≈øent there are ready two Regiments, under the command of Sir Hardes Waller, and four Regiments of the Lord Inchequines, and ≈øix Troops of Hor≈øe under the command of the Earl of Cork; all which are to be li≈øted under the Duke of York, to maintain this unnaturall War again≈øt the Parliament and Kingdom.

Now that it may appear that this Information of Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet is not conjecturall, he is ready to te≈øtific all this upon Oath; And for pre≈øent we have here ≈øent up divers In≈øtruments tending to this effect, ≈øub≈øcribed by the Lord Inchiquine, and delivered to the ≈øaid Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet.

By all this you may perceive what a De≈øigne there is to bring over both Hor≈øe and Foot of the Iri≈øh, to war here again≈øt the Parliament; which might in ≈øome
≈øort have been prevented, if the winter guard had been timely ≈øet forth, which we de≈øire you with all po≈ø≈øible ≈øpeed to ha≈øten the winter guard, as hoping it may be a means to prevent, and intercept a great many of the Iri≈øh Rebells, which daily are in readine≈ø≈øe to come over. And ≈øo, with our be≈øt re≈øpects remembred unto you, praying God to give a ble≈ø≈øing to all your proceedings; We bid you heartily farewell, and re≈øt

closer.signed: William Strickland, Henry Mildmay, Edw. Boys.

div.head: By the Lord of Inchiquine, Commander of His Maje≈øties Forces in chief for the Province of Moun≈øter.
div.p:
VVHereas Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet, Ma≈øter of the Providence of Sandwich, Bur. 100 Tuns; arrived here in this Port of Cork, with his ≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øell from Sandwich, loaden with Corn and other provi≈øions for the u≈øe of His Maje≈øties
army; for which he hath here accordingly duly performed in that particular. And further, I do hereby certifie to whom it may or ≈øhall concern, That I have pre≈ø≈øed the ≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øell, Ma≈øter, Company, and all other provi≈øions to her belonging, for His Maje≈øties ≈øervice, the Ninth day of this pre≈øent October: And is by me commanded, from the ≈øaid day to give his attendance untill further order: For which, he the ≈øaid Ma≈øter may not fail at his perill.

closer.dateline: Given under my hand at Cork, the Ninth day of October, ut ≈øupra, Anno Dom. 1643.

div.head: By the Right Honorable, the Lord of Inchiquine, Commander in chief of his Maje≈øties Forces within the Province of Mounster.
div.p:
VVHereas Thomas Ba≈ø≈øet, Ma≈øter of the good Ship called The Prosperous of Sandwich, Burthen 100 Tuns or thereabouts, Company and ≈øaid Ship, Is imployed by me from this Port of Cork, To carry and tran≈øport
Souldiers for the Port of Bri≈øtoll: And in re≈øpect I finde him obedient, and ready to perform the ≈øaid ≈øervice, I do hereby very earne≈øtly de≈øire the Admirals of His Maje≈øties Fleet, and all others imployed in His ≈øervice, or any other per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever whom it may any way concern, Not any wayes to hinder or mole≈øt him the ≈øaid Ma≈øter, Ship, or Company, or any of them in their departure from the ≈øaid Port of Bri≈øtoll, or in their intended Voyage into Wales, there to lade the ≈øaid Ship with Coals, to be tran≈øported from thence to this Harbour, for the relief of this di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Garri≈øon of Cork; To which purpo≈øe I have ingaged my ≈øelf to the ≈øaid Ma≈øter; and therefore am confident, That my de≈øire herein ≈øhall be complyed withall.

closer.dateline: Dated under my Hand at the ≈øaid city of Cork, this Eighteenth day of October, Anno Dom. 1643.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, my very good Lord, the Lord Hopton, Governour of the City of Bri≈øtoll.
div.p:
I Have imployed this Bearer, Mr. Ba≈ø≈øes, Ma≈øter of a ≈øhip, called The Pro≈øperous of Sandwich, for the tran≈øporting,
and carrying over hence in his ≈øhip, to the Port of Bri≈øtoll ≈øouldiers for His Maje≈øties ≈øervice and have, According to His Maje≈øties Letters, enabling and authorizing mee, agreed with the ≈øaid Ma≈øter, that he ≈øhall be paid fourty pounds ≈øter. for the fraight of his ≈øhip upon her arrivall there; which I conceive to be rea≈øonable: And therefore do de≈øire, not only for the pre≈øent ≈øervice, but al≈øo for the future encouragement of others of his quality: That the ≈øaid money, according to my ≈øaid agreement with him, be forthwith upon his arrivall in that Port punctually paid: Thus, not doubting of the ≈øpeedy performance hereof, I take leave and remaine

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips affectionated friend, and ≈øervant, Inchiquine.

postscript.p: If it be nor proper for your Lord≈øhip to order this payment, I be≈øeech you recommend the Ma≈øter, to whom your Lord≈øhip thinks fit for his ≈øati≈øfaction.

div.head: A Letter from the Governor of Plymouth, To Mr. Speaker of the Honourable Hou≈øe of SIR, COMMONS, The≈øe pre≈øent in London.
div.p:
I Have ≈øent you true Intelligence from Falmouth, one Iohn German comming from Perrin doth report, that two ≈øhips are come to the Pott of Falmouth, From the Rebels in Jreland, with-men,
and ammunition, ≈øhewing the Kings Broad-≈øeale for their ≈øafety; And the Ca≈øtle gave two Peeces of Ordiance, with great joy at their arrivall, with menacing ≈øpeeches again≈øt the Parliament, and ≈øwore the Round heads ≈øhould pay for all: Whereupon ≈øome Captains of the ≈øhips, being men of war there, and divers of the Inhabitants petitioned Iohn Arundel E≈øquire, Governour of Pendennis Ca≈øtle, asking of him, if he would admit entrance to the Rebels; and told him, if he did, many of them would for≈øake that cau≈øe, for good could not po≈ø≈øibly come of it; hee an≈øwered them, that he would ≈øend to know His Maje≈øties plea≈øure in that particular; the Rebels that came from Ireland and Falmouth, report, that they look every day for eleven ≈øhips from Ireland, with men and ammunition, and call them≈øelves the Queens Army; two ≈øhips were al≈øo going to relieve the poore Prote≈øtants in Ireland, and both ≈øtopt at Falmouth, the one laden with wheat, the other with malt: Likewi≈øe there is one Iohn Burla≈ø≈øe E≈øquire, a known Papi≈øt, hath command of a foot Regiment, and governs the We≈øt of the County of Cornwall. Moreover, the ≈øaid German reporteth, that to the fore≈øaid Port of Falmouth, is come four French ≈øhips, landed ≈øome Officers and men, being laden with ammunition, and it is thought, that the Officers are gone to the Kings Army; for they pre≈øently tooke po≈øt from Falmouth, and the ≈øaid French Officers report, that they expect ten thou≈øand men to be ≈øpeedily ≈øent over out of France to them.

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt humble ≈øervant to command, Iames Wardlaw.
